byline.original: By TAMAR LEWIN and MOTOKO RICH

abstract: Senate introduces bipartisan bill revising No Child Left Behind law by reducing reliance on standardized testing for judging success of schools; bill follows pressure from parents and teachers unhappy over failing status of most schools under bill.
lead_paragraph: The proposal retains the requirement for yearly tests, but the federal government would no longer prescribe how the states handle schools with continuously poor scores.

headline.main: Senate Plan to Revise No Child Left Behind Law Would Not Measure Teachers by Test Scores
headline.print_headline: Senate Plan for Education Law Would Not Measure Teachers by Test Scores

snippet: The proposal retains the requirement for yearly tests, but the federal government would no longer prescribe how the states handle schools with continuously poor scores.
